I respect Dr. Krugman immensely but think he is missing the plot on this.

Let's consider the facts: the Bank of England has the lowest nominal interest rates in their 322 year history.

The ECB is purchasing all sovereign debt float, BBB corporate paper, I can only assume cats and dogs next.

The BOJ is discussing "helicopter money" or combining fiscal and monetary policy to engineer inflation by ensuring demand comes with monetary expansion.

Every developed economy seems desperate to depreciate their currency in truest beggar-thy-neighbor fashion.

Since they cannot all depreciate their currencies against one another, they really just want to depreciate against the US dollar. Why is that?

Real USD rates (nominal less core PCE) are negative despite full employment and increasing core inflation as transitory deflationary factors fade.

QE has created bank reserves that are no longer excess after Basel III. Banks globally have no incentive to lend them. Banks are becoming less relevant.

Inflation is not dead. We are seeing extraordinary asset inflation with eye popping price to cash flow multiples.

Central banks were the heroes post-Crisis, but their increasing reliance on loose monetary policy to avoid dealing with structural issues will end up destroying their hard earned credibility.

Risks are most definitely not asymmetric with all due respect.

Well said Nancy and spot on.

The issues remaining won't be fixed by just printing money, but by structural reforms.

Chief amongst them is addressing wealth inequality.

Clearly the richest 23 Americans will not create the same aggregate demand that the poorest 160 million Americans will, though they both have the same resources.

Some great wealthy Americans like Warren Buffett understand the problem well, and have proposed the Buffett rule and other reforms out of common decency.

But some wealthy Americans (see Koch Brothers) view America as their oligarchy and buy political and legal influence to pollute the planet at will and create tax laws that further concentrate wealth.

In addition to improving productivity by rebuilding and enhancing infrastructure;

regressive payroll taxes should be moved to the general budget;

income earned from passive sources and labor should be on parity;

higher education and vocational training should be more affordable;

employer sponsored health care should be replaced by Medicare for all;

and the deferral of taxation before repatriation should be ended for multinationals.

If these structural reforms were enacted, we could well manage aging demographics and would no longer have discussions of declining growth.

But if we just rely on easy money because it is easier to do than structural reforms, expect discussions of weak growth for years to come.

Trump made a very simple and common mistake, that many people have made (on many other issues) -- he saw a video, alright. i saw the same video back in 2001. It showed people celebrating in the streets -- it was at least hundreds, if not thousands -- throwing candy, dancing and laughing. Only it was in Gaza and the West Bank. It was pretty devastating, right in the quake of such an awful tragedy.

Then he ALSO read at least one article about vastly smaller celebrations in New Jersey -- a handful of people, reported in the news. At least one of these articles was by Serge Kovaleski, the disabled reporter Trump was accused of mocking.

If you think about it, the two things dovetail very neatly. Only they are two separate things. Over time, with all the horror and pain of 9/11, they get blurred together.

It isn't fair to say nobody else saw it, or that nobody else conflated these two events (thousands of miles apart). I think honestly that a lot of people think that Muslims were very happy to see a major act of terrorism against the US, especially those engaged in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Hillary did a very similar thing with her tall tales about running from bullets on the tarmac in Bosnia. She conflated STORIES she was told on that trip -- warnings -- actual reports of real incidents -- and her own actual experience (being handed flowers by school children). Is it an out and out lie? Or just the blurring of experiences, that leads someone to mix up different inputs?
Initially the same phenomenon, that's conceivable.  But what came out of Trump's mouth suggests the addition of some purposeful inflation.  Or mental disorder.
Brian Williams had a similar problem.  But the extent of Trump's problem and his response of doubling down make it a whole different ball game.

There is a major problem with objective journalism that predates the Donald. Whether people are lying about matters of fact or the validity of logical conclusions is itself a matter of fact. But circumstantial evidence is enough to establish that fact even in the face of their denials only for people outside the mainstream. For mainstream figures their denials must be reported on the same level as the matters of fact; otherwise, bias is present and objectivity is gone.

But for the Donald, the problem is much worse. He claims to have seen a video of many Jersey City residents celebrating the World Trade Center's destruction, but no one else did and no one can find any such video. The truth is that he is seeing things that do not exist, or making them up. Objective reporting is to report what he claims to have seen and note that no one else saw it, rather than to report that he is seeing things or that a proven tendency of his to see things is manifesting itself again.

Objective reporting panders to those who make things up by reporting what they made up and that others disagree instead of reporting that they made something up and maybe describing what it was. For the sake of "balance" and "objectivity" and to keep customers who side with those making things up, known liars and spinners and public relations people are treated with a deference that erases the distinction between an honest account and a smooth spiel.

The short answer to the question in this op-ed's headline is "we don't have to."

From my most recent essay on this very topic:

"Should one accept at face value Julian Assange’s assertion that he is able to separate his personal feelings from his judgment as Editor-In-Chief? The answer to that question is best answered with two questions:

1. has anyone questioned the authenticity of the DNC data dump?

The answer to that question is an obvious no. Would Debbie Wasserman Schultz have resigned if there was any possibility of claiming that the leaked emails were somehow altered or even falsified? Obviously, they were not.

But that hasn’t stopped Wasserman Schultz from stating that she “took one for the team” by resigning from the DNC

2. Would it even matter if it turned out that we have the DNC emails thanks to Russia?

In the final analysis, the answer has to be no, especially when one factors in the fact that the chair of an organization’s duties include being aware of external dangers, as Wasserman Schultz demonstrated she is capable of when there was a question about the Sanders campaign having had access to Clinton campaign data."

See: http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2n0

What the media focused us away from is the leaks themselves. How Assange does or doesn't curate his materials is beside the point. Any curation would have invalidated the data dump even more than the Russian angle has in the current public discussion. The DNC has a big problem. That should be the only focus.
In fact, all those other things were objective truths, too, that needed to be reported and were!

It was objective journalism to say that President Johnson had a credibility gap about Vietnam. It would have been less objective to report that many people were having trouble believing him on Vietnam, even less to report that many people did not believe him, and even less to report that he was dissembling or evading on Vietnam.

The end result of this sort of objectivity is that we get fashion reporting on the Emperor's new wardrobe.
It seems that counterfeit news drives real news out of circulation, and journalists have not figured out how to deal with that yet.
